evidence: a primary electron beam, accelerated toward the target, passes close to the nucleus of a tungsten atom
high-energy primary electron collides with an inner-shell electron
energy difference between the two shells is released in the form of an X-ray photon
an X-ray tube produces the mixture of radiation
Since the amount of bending can vary, the emitted X-rays span a continuous range of energies. That’s why Bremsstrahlung is also called continuous radiation.

The second mechanism is called characteristic radiation... that radiation is X-rays. Because the energy levels of atomic shells are discrete, the emitted X-ray has a very specific energy - a "characteristic" value that depends on the target material.
This is what I call our first “red diamond,” or key concept.
The answer lies in two main physical mechanisms.
The first mechanism is called Bremsstrahlung radiation, a German word meaning “braking radiation.”
The second mechanism is called characteristic radiation, sometimes explained in terms of the photoelectric effect.
Bremsstrahlung gives us a broad, continuous X-ray spectrum, while characteristic radiation adds sharp peaks at specific energies.
Together, these two processes explain how an X-ray tube produces the mixture of radiation that we use for imaging.
